component:ember-selects/components/selec.title: SelectListbox
component:ember-selects/components/selec.text:
Render a custom listbox element. Can be used in block-form or inline form. Yields an option object which can be used to customize each option in the listbox. # inline {{select-listbox onChange=(action (mut selectedName)) selected=selectedName options=(array 'Steve' 'Bill' 'Katie')}} # block {{#select-listbox onChange=(action 'selectUser') selected=selectedUser options=users as |option| }}
{{option.name}} ({{option.userId}})
{{/select-listbox}}

attributes.name: SelectListbox
attributes.description:
Render a custom listbox element. Can be used in block-form or inline form. Yields an option object which can be used to customize each option in the listbox.

# inline

{{select-listbox
  onChange=(action (mut selectedName))
  selected=selectedName
  options=(array 'Steve' 'Bill' 'Katie')}}

# block

{{#select-listbox
  onChange=(action 'selectUser')
  selected=selectedUser
  options=users 
  as |option|
}}
  <div>
    <img src={{option.avatarUrl}} alt="" />
    <strong>{{option.name}}</strong> ({{option.userId}})
  </div>
{{/select-listbox}}

arguments.name: placeholder
arguments.description:
The placeholder option in your listbox. By default this will be empty. If a selection is already made, the placeholder will not be present.

{{select-listbox placeholder='Select a thing'}}

arguments.name: aria-label
arguments.description:
Adds an aria-label string to the select element

{{select-listbox aria-label='Select your preference'}}

arguments.name: aria-labelledby
arguments.description:
Adds an aria-labelledby string to the select element. This must referrence the id of another dom element that contains text that labels the select.

{{select-listbox aria-labelledby='id-of-the-labelling-element'}}

arguments.name: disabled
arguments.description:
When true, adds the disabled boolean attribute to the input element

{{select-listbox disabled=true}}

arguments.name: required
arguments.description:
When true, adds the required and aria-required boolean attributes to the select element

{{select-listbox required=true}}

arguments.name: allowClear
arguments.description:
When true, adds a button element next to the select that calls onChange with an empty string

{{select-listbox allowClear=true}}

arguments.name: options
arguments.description:
This required array represents the options available to be selected. A few different formats are supported for this object:

{{select-listbox options=users}}
# array of strings
users: [
  'steve', 
  'bill', 
  'katie'
]
# array of objects with default keys
users: [
  { value: '1', label: 'steve', disabled: false },
  { value: '2', label: 'bill', disabled: false },
  { value: '3', label: 'katie', disabled: false }
]
# array of objects with custom keys
users: [
  { customValue: '1', customLabel: 'steve', customDisabled: false },
  { customValue: '2', customLabel: 'bill', customDisabled: false },
  { customValue: '3', customLabel: 'katie', customDisabled: false }
]

When using custom property keys, you must declare these keys using the valueKey (required), labelKey (optional), and disabledKey (optional) arguments.

arguments.name: selected
arguments.description:
This argument represents the currently selected option.

This argument should match the format of the items in your options array.

If options is an array of strings, then selected must be a string that matches one of the strings in the options array.

If options is an array of objects, then selected must be a object with a value property (or valueKey) that is equal to the value property (or valueKey) of one of the objects in the options array.

{{select-listbox selected='my option 1'}}

arguments.name: valueKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option value should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-listbox valueKey='customValue'}}

arguments.name: labelKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option label should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-listbox labelKey='customLabel'}}

arguments.name: disabledKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option disabled state should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-listbox disabledKey='customDisabled'}}

arguments.name: onFocus
arguments.description: a custom function that is run when the listbox receives focus

arguments.name: onBlur
arguments.description: a custom function that is run when the listbox loses focus

arguments.name: onChange
arguments.description:
This function is run whenever a selection is made by the user.

This function must change the value ofselected

component:ember-selects/components/selec.title: SelectNative
component:ember-selects/components/selec.text: Render a native select element. Can be used in block-form or inline form. Yields an option object which can be used to customize each option in the select. {{!-- inline form --}} {{select-native onchange=(action 'changeMySelected') selected=mySelected options=myOption}} {{!-- block form --}} {{#select-native onchange=(action 'changeMySelected') selected=mySelected options=myOption as |option| }} option.name (#{{option.id}}) {{/select-native}}

attributes.name: SelectNative
attributes.description:
Render a native select element. Can be used in block-form or inline form. Yields an option object which can be used to customize each option in the select.

{{!-- inline form --}}

{{select-native
  onchange=(action 'changeMySelected')
  selected=mySelected
  options=myOption}}

{{!-- block form --}}

{{#select-native
  onchange=(action 'changeMySelected')
  selected=mySelected
  options=myOption as |option|
}}
  option.name (#{{option.id}})
{{/select-native}}

arguments.name: class
arguments.description: A string of css classes to be applied to the wrapping div. Defaults to select-native

arguments.name: focusedClass
arguments.description: A string of css classes to be conditionally applied to the wrapping div when the select element is focused. Defaults to select-native--focus

arguments.name: selectClass
arguments.description: A string of css classes to be applied to the select element. Defaults to select-native__select

arguments.name: optionClass
arguments.description: A string of css classes to be applied to each option element. Defaults to select-native__option Note: most browsers will ignore any styles applied to this class

arguments.name: placeholder
arguments.description:
The placeholder option in your select. By default this will produce an empty option. If a selection is already made, the placeholder will not be present.

{{select-native placeholder='Please make a selection'}}

arguments.name: aria-label
arguments.description:
Adds an aria-label string to the select element.

{{select-native aria-label='Select your preference'}}

arguments.name: aria-labelledby
arguments.description:
Adds an aria-labelledby string to the select element. This must referrence the id of another dom element that contains text that labels the select.

{{select-native aria-labelledby='id-of-the-labelling-element'}}

arguments.name: disabled
arguments.description:
When true, adds the disabled boolean attribute to the select element

{{select-native disabled=true}}

arguments.name: required
arguments.description:
When true, adds the required and aria-required boolean attributes to the select element

{{select-native required=true}}

arguments.name: options
arguments.description:
This required array represents the options available to be selected. A few different formats are supported for this object:

{{select-native options=users}}
# array of strings
users: [
  'steve', 
  'bill', 
  'katie'
]
# array of objects with default keys
users: [
  { value: '1', label: 'steve', disabled: false },
  { value: '2', label: 'bill', disabled: false },
  { value: '3', label: 'katie', disabled: false }
]
# array of objects with custom keys
users: [
  { customValue: '1', customLabel: 'steve', customDisabled: false },
  { customValue: '2', customLabel: 'bill', customDisabled: false },
  { customValue: '3', customLabel: 'katie', customDisabled: false }
]

When using custom property keys, you must declare these keys using the valueKey (required), labelKey (optional), and disabledKey (optional) arguments.

arguments.name: selected
arguments.description:
This argument represents the currently selected option.

This argument should match the format of the items in your options array.

If options is an array of strings, then selected must be a string that matches one of the strings in the options array.

If options is an array of objects, then selected must be a object with a value property (or valueKey) that is equal to the value property (or valueKey) of one of the objects in the options array.

{{select-native selected='my option 1'}}

arguments.name: valueKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option value should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-native valueKey='customValue'}}

arguments.name: labelKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option label should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-native labelKey='customLabel'}}

arguments.name: disabledKey
arguments.description:
Declares a custom key for which the option disabled state should be gotten from each object in the options array

{{select-native disabledKey='customDisabled'}}

arguments.name: onfocus
arguments.description:
a custom function that is run when the select receives focus

{{select-native onfocus=(action 'customOnFocus'}}

arguments.name: onblur
arguments.description:
a custom function that is run when the select loses focus

{{select-native onblur=(action 'customOnBlur'}}

arguments.name: onchange
arguments.description:
a custom function that is run when the user makes a selection

{{select-native onchange=(action 'customOnChange'}}

template:docs/index.title: What is ember-selects?
template:docs/index.text: What is ember-selects? ember-selects was born out of a need to have a limited, focused set of UI components that allow users to select things. The HTML select element doesn't get us very far, so most ember developers eventually reach for a more robust solution. It turns out that selects are a suprisingly easy thing for ambitious developers to get wrong (or only half right). The existing solutions for select elements in the ember ecosystem are either half-baked, just a wrapper around a jquery library, or give you too much rope to hang yourself with. ember-selects aims to remove the guess work from implementing ambitious select UI by giving you a narrow, focused set of excellent out-of-the-box select components that are sufficiently customizable and a breeze to work with. In pursuit of these design goal, ember-selects makes a few very deliberate API choices that you should be aware of upfront: Accessible out of the box ember-selects exposes a set of components that offer out-of-the-box accessibility by implementing established WAI-ARIA patterns, so it works for all your users without you doing a thing. Blackboxed Selects are a very easy thing to get wrong once you leave the safety of HTML's built in select element. ember-selects offers a set of blackboxed components that are hard to break but a breeze to work with. Customizable visual design ember-selects is designed to be designed. It ships with a set of basic styles and gets out of the way so that you can style it to match your app. Implement established ui patterns ember-selects doesn't reinvent the wheel, it implements established UI patterns that are already part of the WAI-ARIA specs - things like listbox, combobox, and menu. You'll need to understand these patterns to understand which select component to use for a give use case. Don't be everything to everyone ember-selects is not here to give you a maximally configurable, composable or customizable API. In fact, it basically give you no rope to hang your self with at all. Instead, ember-selects offers a limited set of components that each do one thing and do it well. This means that ember-selects might not meet your need if you have a particularly unique design or UI pattern to implement. Built with ember, for ember ember-selects is built from the ground up with ember code and ember conventions, so it Just Works with async, promises, ember objects, etc. No external js libraries were involved in the creation of this addon. Built for performance ember-selects offers opt-in tree-shaking, so you only need to ship the components that you are actually using in your app.

template:docs/quickstart.title: Quickstart
template:docs/quickstart.text: Quickstart This quickstart guide will get you started using ember-selects in your ember app. After completion you'll understand which select component to use for different use cases, and how ember-selects can improve your select Installation ember install ember-selects The Components ember-selects exposes 4 primary components for use in your app. When starting out its important to understand which component to use for various use-cases. select-native This component is merely a convenient component wrapper around the native HTML select element. Use this when your don't need multiple selection, your options only need to display text (no html), and you'd like to take advantage of the browser native look and feel of the select menu (especially important on mobile browsers). select-listbox This component is an implementation of the WAI-ARIA listbox pattern, basically a more flexible version of html's select element. Supports single or multi select, and arbitrary option html. Use this when you need full control over the options (ie. arbitrary html) or you need the option of allowing multiple selections. select-combobox This component is an implementation of the WAI-ARIA combobox pattern, aka autocomplete. Use this when you need an autocomplete-style input where the user is shown a list of suggestions as they type. select-menu This component is an implementation of the WAI-ARIA menu pattern. Use this when presenting the user with a menu of actions rather than a list of selectable options. Usage Each ember-selects component can be invoked with a similar component API, in either inline or block form. In it's simplest form, an ember-selects component takes an array of strings of possible options, a selected option string, and an onchange action. For more complicated use cases, you can use the block form to customize the rendered option, and use objects instead of strings to represent the options. Tree shaking ember-selects is built to be treeshakable, so you opt-in to the components you need, or opt-out of the components you don't need. Details coming soon.
